content:
I’m a Postdoctoral Scholar at Berkeley AI Research (BAIR) Lab and the Center for Human-Compatible AI (CHAI). I recently received my Ph.D. in EECS from UC Berkeley advised by Stuart Russell and Jiantao Jiao.
My research is on mathematical foundations of AI and designing capable and general-purpose AI systems for reliable integration into the real world. My recent research has been focusing on reinforcement learning and machine learning algorithms for autonomous inference, prediction, and decision-making. I also work on machine learning applications in areas such as healthcare, robotics, autonomous driving, and systems.
summary: I’m a Postdoctoral Scholar at Berkeley AI Research (BAIR) Lab and the Center for Human-Compatible AI (CHAI). I recently received my Ph.D. in EECS from UC Berkeley advised by Stuart Russell and Jiantao Jiao.
title: Paria Rashidinejad
Efficient Online and Offline Reinforcement Learning via Offline Regression Oracles

summary: We propose a statistically optimal offline RL algorithm based on marginalized importance sampling  and actor-critc method, which is computationally efficient and requires weaker dataset coverage.
title: Importance Weighted Actor-Critic for Optimal Conservative Offline Reinforcement Learning

summary: We propose statistically optimal and practical conservative offline RL algorithms with general function approximation.
title: Optimal Conservative Offline RL with General Function Approximation via Augmented Lagrangian

summary: We propose a new formulation for offline RL that describes the entire range of dataset compositions, hence unifying imitation learning and vanilla offline RL. Equipped with this formulation, we prove that *pessimism in the face of uncertainty* is almost optimal for solving offline RL problems, regardless of the unknown data composition.
title: Bridging Offline Reinforcement Learning and Imitation Learning: A Tale of Pessimism

summary: Exploration in online reinforcement learning is particularly challenging in high-dimensional complex environments that provide little feedback. Motivated by current practical challenges and the gap between theory and practice, we propose a new algorithm for exploration by maximizing deviation from explored regions. The approach results in a simple modification to existing deep RL exploration methods and achieves state-of-the-art performance on navigation and locomotion tasks.
title: MADE: Exploration via Maximizing Deviation from Explored Regions
Bridging Offline Reinforcement Learning and Imitation Learning: A Tale of Pessimism
SLIP: Learning to Predict in Unknown Dynamical Systems with Long-Term Memory

summary: Making predictions in unknown dynamical systems remains a challenge particularly when the system is only marginally stable and exhibits long forecast memory. In this work, we propose an online learning algorithm called SLIP for making predictions in unknown and partially-observed dynamical systems. We prove that the proposed algorithm converges to optimal predictions in finite samples, with a convergence rate independent of both forecast memory and system’s degree of stability.
title: SLIP: Learning to Predict in Unknown Dynamical Systems with Long-Term Memory

summary: We present a patient-adaptable probabilistic framework for intracranial morphology segmentation, used to detect acute brain injuries.
title: Patient-Adaptable Intracranial Pressure Morphology Analysis Using a Probabilistic Model-Based Approach

summary: Techniques are described herein for accurately measuring the reliability of storage systems. Rather than relying on a series of approximations, which may produce highly optimistic estimates, the techniques described herein use a failure distribution derived from a disk failure data set to derive reliability metrics such as mean time to data loss (MTTDL) and annual durability. A new framework for modeling storage system dynamics is described herein. The framework facilitates theoretical analysis of the reliability. The model described herein captures the complex structure of storage systems considering their configuration, dynamics, and operation. Given this model, a simulation-free analytical solution to the commonly used reliability metrics is derived. The model may also be used to analyze the long-term reliability behavior of storage systems.
title: Techniques for Accurately Estimating the Reliability of Storage Systems
